node.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Almost 800,000 U.S. Covid Deaths
node.alt: A memorial honoring Los Angeles residents who died from Covid.
node.description: People 65 and older are the most vulnerable.
node.content: ["As the pandemic nears the end of a second year, the U.S. stands on the cusp of surpassing 800,000 deaths from the coronavirus.", "No group has suffered more than older Americans. Seventy-five percent of those who have died in the U.S. are 65 or older. Covid-19 has killed one in 100 Americans in that age group. For people younger than 65, that ratio is closer to 1 in 1,400.", "The heightened risk for older people has dominated life for many, partly as friends and family try to protect them. \u201cYou get kind of forgotten,\u2019\u2019 said Pat Hayashi, 65, of San Francisco. \u201cIn the pandemic, the isolation and the loneliness got worse. We lost our freedom and we lost our services.\u201d", "Many have watched others in their communities go back to life as normal, and companies have pushed to get people back into the workplace. \u201cThere\u2019s all these ways \u2014 subtle, overt, direct, indirect \u2014 that we are not taking the needs of older people in this pandemic into account,\u201d said Louise Aronson, a geriatrician and the author of \u201cElderhood.\u201d", "Current data: Vaccines are widely available in the U.S., and older Americans have been inoculated at a much higher rate than young people: 87 percent of those 65 and older have been fully vaccinated. But in the past two months, the proportion of older people dying of Covid has increased. More than 1,200 people in the U.S. are dying from the virus each day, most of them 65 or older.", "Here are the latest updates and maps of the pandemic.", "In other developments:", "A Hong Kong court on Monday sentenced the former media mogul Jimmy Lai and seven other prominent pro-democracy activists to prison for their roles last year in trying to commemorate the Tiananmen Square crackdown.", "The sentences ranged from four months to 14 months. In statements read in court before the sentencing, Lai and his co-defendants made clear that they felt no regret for defying the government\u2019s ban.", "Chow Hang-tung, one of the defendants, delivered an impassioned statement condemning the government for using public health reasons to justify what she called an explicitly political prosecution. \u201cLet us not delude ourselves that this is all about Covid-19,\u201d she said.", "Background: Activists gathered on June 4 last year before an annual vigil to honor the victims of Beijing\u2019s 1989 suppression of protesters in Tiananmen Square. The government had banned the gathering, which has taken place for three decades, citing coronavirus concerns.", "What\u2019s next: Lai and other defendants separately face charges under the national security law, which can bring sentences up to life imprisonment.", "Prime Minister Naftali Bennett and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed met for four hours \u2014 two hours longer than planned \u2014 in the first official visit to the U.A.E. by an Israeli leader, the latest sign of deepening ties between Israel and parts of the Arab world.", "\u201cI\u2019m flying back to Israel, very optimistic that this relationship can set an example of how we can make peace here in the Middle East,\u201d Bennett said in a video released shortly before his departure to Israel.", "The pair did not discuss the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, according to an Israeli official who declined to comment on what regional geopolitical issues were mentioned.", "Reporters were barred from the meeting, but photographs showed the leaders chatting informally and laughing. The leaders pledged to establish a joint Emirati-Israeli research and development fund, as well as a business council, according to a joint statement.", "Main concerns: Iran remains a major threat to Emirati security, and the Emiratis share Israel\u2019s fear that Iran will attain a nuclear bomb. But their country is a major trading partner with Iran and it favors a less confrontational approach than Israel. The pair\u2019s statement said they had also discussed trade, the economy, the climate and food security.", "A global rise in prices is changing the political terrain for the right-wing populists leading countries like Turkey, Brazil and Hungary, who have enjoyed wide support for years. The cost of living and low wages are becoming top concerns for voters.", "Given both the technical progress being made and the business push behind it, we\u2019re far more likely than our predecessors were to actually embrace the prospect of life in a virtual world, according to David J. Chalmers, a philosopher at New York University. It needn\u2019t be rooted in visions of dystopia, he told The Times in an interview about his forthcoming book, \u201cReality+.\u201d", "\u201cMy analogy would be more like we\u2019re moving to a new, uninhabited country and setting up a society,\u201d Chalmers said.", "Besides, he added, the recent evolution of virtual reality means we should be taking more seriously the age-old philosophical debate that we already live in a simulation \u2014 which could be neat.", "\u201cDiscovering that we\u2019re in a simulation would then also tell us that there\u2019s potentially a reality beyond the reality that we experience, which is the reality of the simulating world,\u201d Chalmers said, \u201cand who knows what\u2019s going on there?\u201d", "In the more immediate future, Facebook is trying to stake out the metaverse for itself. The writer who coined the term, Neal Stephenson, told Kara Swisher that we should unionize to prevent virtual worlds from becoming dystopias.", "This shrimp and bean stew requires minimal prep and cooks quickly.", "The best poetry of the year, according to our columnist.", "Silent films made by an American ornithologist in the early years of Irish independence offer a rare glimpse of 1920s Ireland.", "Here\u2019s today\u2019s Mini Crossword, and a clue: Fret (five letters).", "And here is today\u2019s Spelling Bee.", "You can find all our puzzles here.", "That\u2019s it for today\u2019s briefing. See you next time. \u2014 Melina", "P.S. A hidden haiku from a story about a Ukrainian soldier who worries for his children: \u201cThey give him strength, but / he fears what would happen if / he didn\u2019t come back.\u201d", "The latest episode of \u201cThe Daily\u201d is about the quiet death of the Steele dossier.", "You can reach Melina and the team at briefing@nytimes.com."]
